This technology is particularly useful due to its transparency and security. Once a block is added to the chain, it becomes extremely difficult to remove or alter it. 

Here's an example to make it more relevant. Suppose you and your friend exchanged some money. This transaction would be stored as a block on the blockchain. It would contain information on how much money was transferred, as well as timestamps and unique identifiers for both you and your friend.

So, this makes blockchain very useful for situations where it's critical to know that a record hasn't been tampered with, like tracking the supply chain of goods or maintaining a currency, just like Bitcoin.

The real life applications of machine learning are numerous. One of the most commonly known uses is recommendation system. For instance, companies like Netflix and Amazon use machine learning algorithms to suggest films or products based on customers' prior habits. Quantum physics, also known as quantum mechanics, is an area of physics that deals with phenomena on a very small scale, like molecules, atoms, and subatomic particles. Now, imagine a small grain of sand. Quantum physics is what happens if you break that grain down over a billion times smaller to the level of single atoms and particles.

Think of it as being similar to the different rules between normal sports and mini versions of the same. In the same way, Quantum physics is like the mini version of our understanding of physics, except the rules can seem quite strange to us.

For instance, in the quantum world, a particle can be in two places at the same time - strange, right? This is known as quantum superposition. There's also a phenomenon called quantum entanglement where particles can become linked, and the state of one instantly influences the other no matter the distance between them.

I hope this gives you a basic understanding. Please note that quantum physics is incredibly complex and requires years of study to fully understand, and a deeper understanding of mathematics and physics.
